{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3344865,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-27T02:07:21.266Z","cooked":"

Inspired by the damage to bumpers and frames this year, the Give A Little topic from the latest off-season, and 4907‚Äôs 2022 jumping robot Darth Theta, I ask: is it time to separate the chassis and the frame perimeter (FP) to control/limit damage?

Rules Breakdown: The FP cannot be articulated per R101 [2024 rules throughout], and the bumpers can‚Äôt be articulated relative to the FP per R403, but as several of us noticed and 4907 implemented to great acclaim in 2022, the chassis of the robot (that is, drive train, manipulators, and generally anything other than the frame perimeter and bumpers) may be articulated or non-rigidly mounted relative to the FP. We can take advantage of this to reduce damage, even if we don‚Äôt have a need to jump.

My suggestion: mount a minimal FP to the chassis with springs or padding or whatever shock limiting mount you can come up with rather than rigidly. There are plenty of ways to skin this cat, but here‚Äôs a simple and lightweight one provided to get thoughts flowing: Build your robot with what would have traditionally been an FP of 112" or less. Then make a rules-proper FP from a piece of aluminum bar (up to 10‚Äô long, probably 4" wide*, but not necessarily very thick) bent so that it is an inch away from your ‚Äúold style FP‚Äù (OSFP) and (importantly) fits tight inside the bumpers. Put a layer of 1" thick closed cell foam between your OSFP and actual FP. Secure things all around in accordance with the rules. (not trivial, but quite doable). Congratulations, you‚Äôve added what I estimate to be at least 50% to the give of the bumper system and likely 70%. Further, the rule FP is really easy to repair if it gets bent and is also cheap to replace if it comes to that.
If you go this route, I suggest you prioritize flexibility of your bumper wood over actual strength. Baltic Birch sounds cold; I yew in this bumper model. [Both puns admittedly intentional.]

Oh, by the way, you can use those two additional inches for your mechanisms, because at the start of the match, they are inside your frame perimeter.

Oh, also by the way, there are no rules I can find against having 2 (or more) FRAME PERIMETERS that you swap out between red and blue matches, and support for this bumper model from 104E, replacement of a MECHANISM with an identical MECHANISM. If you decide that you‚Äôd rather mount your equivalent FPs dynamically to the chassis during the event, go for it. Just be ready to separate them for initial inspection.

* Because bar bending tools for up to 4" are so much easier to buy than for wider widths; this seems close enough to the nominal 5" bumper heights to be a win for many teams.
